Posts.Content:
Sorry you haven't had any replies. I don't know what the problem is either.
It's worthwhile to see your doctor, GP or gyne. It's probably not a big deal, but it's. Always good to be reassured.
Posts.Title: my left breast has been experiencing a burning sensation

Posts.Content:
I tried all 3 AIs and tamoxifen too. They all gave me such pain, all the other side effects, that I had to stop taking anything. I ended up having trigger finger surgery from the effects of the meds.
After a year being off the meds I am still not interested in sex, and it hurts too much to even try. Fortunately there are other ways to satisfy our partners, and they do deserve to have us try.
Posts.Title: femara side effects - loss of sex drive, vaginal dryiness and sensitivity et al

Posts.Content:
Unless th doc comes up with something like infection, Nerves regenerating is baloney. Like me, you've been cooked. 
Check under your armpit for auxilary cording. Look it up. I got it from radiation. 
I got mine fixed, not perfectly or forever, by a physical therapist - maybe an occupational therapist. She crunched the cord, which is the cooked lymphatic system, and most of the pain went away immediately. Don't get too many sessions and not more than twice a week. I still have to stretch after 6 years.
Try to find a local cancer group to refer you to a therapist. There are very few trained in this.
Posts.Title: After Radiation

Posts.Content:
I went to a seminar once where we patients suggested bad side effects might be related to age or problems like arthritis we might already have. From posts I have seen it seems the older the patient the worse the pain.
I've been off all the meds for 2 years now, just getting blood tests twice a year. But I had only a small tumor with oncotype only 7 and I had very low estrogen to start with.
My gynecologist mentioned estrogen cream but thought it was too dangerous with an estrogen positive tumor history even though only 1% is absorbed throughout the body.
Sex is still impossible for me, but I do try as often as I can to take care of my spouse in other ways.
Posts.Title: femara side effects - loss of sex drive, vaginal dryiness and sensitivity et al

Posts.Content:
Not toes, but 3 pills of Aromasin was all it took to give me the trigger fingers and the most horrible arthritis-like pain, so bad I couldn't take any more. I had tried Arimidex, didn't tolerate after 3 months. Then came Femara, which I put up with for half a year, but was practically crawling to the kitchen for Rx pain meds.
The trigger fingers came on fast - three days - and they didn't go away even though I stopped the Aromasin, so I had to have surgery after a year of pain.
I think docs just believe what the drug companies tell them - generally well tolerated - unless patients figure it out for themselves and complain. In truth, many women seem not to be particularly bothered, but older women with tendencies toward arthritis have a bad time. I'm part of a study group at U. Pit.
Posts.Title: femara side effects - loss of sex drive, vaginal dryiness and sensitivity et al

Posts.Content:
The Femara website has a coupon for $10 Femara, good for a year. 
Unfortunately, if you are on Medicare or Medicaid you can't use it. There may be another assistance program for those of us on Medicare, but you have to call and then they fax some form to your oncologist. I haven't heard if I will be able to get any help yet.
This one drug will cost me $4500 out of pocket this year - even with my insurance - because I am over 65. 
Since you have to be post-menopausal to take aromatase inhibitors, that means most of us who take these drugs are being hit unfairly hard.
Maybe someone else knows of another program to cut the cost? I'm seriously considering taking it every other day.
Posts.Title: Questions about Femara and pain

Posts.Content:
Xen
Wow that's great news! Why then, do they put us on a one-size-fits-all dose? Can you give me a citation for the info? I will look on the Femara site. Is it all there?
I gave up on Femara, couldn't stand the pain. Was switched to Aromasin. Pain was incredibly worse and after three days i got trigger fingers! I've been off all AIs for a couple of months now. I can't use the computer mouse with my right hand, 3 fingers triggering there, one on right, having trouble typing. I'm scheduled for surgery to release trigger fingers next week. I've also been getting spinal injections for sciatica since on AIs. I also have gotten pinched nerves in my neck causing arm numbness.
I believe if you have preexisting conditions like arthritis the AIs will dramatically make it worse. Just a casual observation. I only have a tiny couple of spots of arthritis in my hands, but have had it in my spine. I didn't have serious problems until starting AIs.
I'll talk it over with my onc. I like being off everything, but I'm scared silly the cancer could come back or another one could pop up. I printed out your post to study,
Posts.Title: Questions about Femara and pain

Posts.Content:
LSS
Thanks for the tip. I'm sitting here crying in pain waiting for my oncologist to call back. I started taking the Femara again, but only every other day. I've tripled my Rx pain meds and tried adding OTC meds, but it's just awful. I feel like quitting. My pain docs don't deal with this stuff. 
Bev
Thanks for the website, but I couldn't find any real info, no qualifications, no contact info, just bragging about
 how they offer help with some meds. Supposedly they are faxing something to my oncologist, from the call I made on the Femara website. But that was last week and I haven't heard anything. I'm not sure I want to keep on this drug anyway.
Posts.Title: Questions about Femara and pain

Posts.Content:
I finally just stopped taking any of the AIs, with the unenthusiastic OK from my oncologist, whom I have stopped seeing. The last one, Aromasin gave me such pain that I didn't want to live after only 3 pills. It gave me 3 trigger fingers, which I have just had operated.
I'm concerned with not taking anything, but I don't tolerate any of them. I would as soon die as suffer horribly like I was doing. 
What makes me mad is that the Femara website says that the drug is effective even at 1/5th the dose we are forced to take. I don't believe in one pill fits all. I'm old, don't have much estrogen to begin with, and I am not very heavy. But no matter, I would have to take the same dose as some young person 500lbs. Or nothing.
I stopped going to the oncologist, not because he was bad, and he was very good, but he was in a clinic that charged me a clinic fee when I got no service but a chair. Medicare doesn't pay for it either! I'd go to another one if I could find one that only charges for an office visit, but all the oncology practices have been bought up by the university and do the same thing.
Posts.Title: Questions about Femara and pain

Posts.Content:
There is a lot of research being done on the side effects of the aromatase inhibitors and tamoxifen at the University of Pittsburgh. I was lucky enough to attend one of the meetings of patients and researchers. 
It seems to me that the older you are the worse the side effects. My opinion partly from my side effects as an older person. I tried all 4 meds, didn't tolerate any of them. Severe pain, horrible arthritis-like symptoms, fingers curled until I ended up with trigger finger surgery. I lost some hair that didn't come back, but that could have been radiation. 
Since I had a low oncotype, I quit all the meds. That was a year ago. I see oncologist twice a year for blood tests, get mammogram once a year. I feel much better now.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen Side Effects

Posts.Content:
Aha! I went back to the Femara website and found the pdf file we need to read at http://www.pharma.us.novartis.com/product/pi/pdf/Femara.pdf. I didn't yet find Xen's info about
 dissolving the pill in ethyl alcohol (make sure not to use rubbing alcohol!!!), but the info about
 .5 being effective is there. So again, why are we being fed 2.5 mg no matter our age or size???
I will discuss this with my onc. I don't think he's considered the study. I would go back on it if I didn't have to suffer so.
Posts.Title: Questions about Femara and pain

Posts.Content: Bev
Posts.Title: Questions about Femara and pain

Posts.Content:
Bev
Thanks for the support.
I went to the oncologists office - 2 hours through horrible snow, accidents all over the place, including right in front of me! My BP was a little high by the time I got there.
I told the onc I couldn't tolerate more than taking Femara every other day and even that was making life not worthwhile living. No, I way not suicidal! But the Femara pain was getting as bad as the Arimidex pain, which I refused to take after only a month. So he put me on Aromasin. I was so exhausted after 1 1/2 hours driving home that I just collapsed and got the pills the next day.
First Aromasin pill was nearly as bad as the first Arimidex, which caused me to pass out. I had headache, severe nausea (scarey because I can't vomit since stomach surgery to pull my stomach out of my chest after car wreck), horrible muscle cramps in thighs, chest pain, and severe dizziness from low blood pressure to the point where I couldn't get off the couch long enough to get a phone across the room to call for help.
Second pill, today, much better taken with a large breakfast. Nausea a couple of hours later, but tolerable, dizziness, severe tinnitus which hasn't stopped, but other symptoms better. I'm hoping the muscle pain from the Femara will eventually subside, but this one can cause pain too. At least I have not had to take Vicodin for 2 days! :)
I've been informed of two reliable (according to people who have used them) places to get cheaper meds: Xubex.com in FL and Alldaychemist.com. I simply can't get help, because I am on Medicare, so I'm going to buy my meds wherever I have to. I'll try out Aromasin from my local pharmacist first for a month to see if it's any better.
Alternative is tamoxifen, but I have all my pieces-parts, and stroke and heart attack run in the family, so that is a fair-size risk. But I won't just keep taking pain meds for whatever life I have left!
Posts.Title: Questions about Femara and pain

Posts.Content:
Hi
I originally started on Arimidex and had such pain I couldn't stand it after only a month and a half. Like arthritis + fibromyalgia X 10. Actually I have both, so maybe it just makes them worse.
I have been taking Femara for about
 8 months and the same pain as Arimidex has finally caused me to take a vacation from it. I've been off for 10 days and don't really feel any better. So how long does it take to feel better, or is the pain maybe not actually from the Femara at all?
Posts.Title: Questions about Femara and pain

Posts.Content:
Hi 10 rings -
Just take the med and see what happens. Everyone reacts differently. Your doc prescribed it because it works and doesn't cause bad side effects in most patients.
I took my first med (Arimidex) for a month before I realized I needed to change it. I have been taking Femara about
 8 months, and just now I am taking a vacation from it (2 - 3 weeks) to see if my pains are from my fibromyalgia and arthritis or the med. After 10 eays off it I can't see any difference, so I will restart it in another week and see if I feel worse.
Posts.Title: Questions about Femara and pain

Posts.Content:
Sunni
Twinges are to be expected. I have them where I still have feeling after my little lumpectomy. Numbness is to be expected too. After all, nerves were cut! I have that too, over about
 1/3 of my breast. Be happy it was benign! You should have some followup, but maybe not for 6 months or even a year. If nothing was scheduled, call and ask about
 it. It will at least ease your mind if they say you don't need anything.
Even this little surgery could possibly cause post-traumatic-stress-syndrome. It would be expected if the lump was malignant. I found a local cancer caring group to go to to talk with women who have had similar experiences. They'll all be worse than you, many stage 4, but they can answer your questions and give you some support.
Posts.Title: After excisional breast biopsy - scar tissue?

Posts.Content: Is there any possibility of contacting a support group in your area? Maybe someone would be willing to drive her to meetings or at least visit. It's so hard for a cancer patient to talk to friends and relatives who do not have experience, but many of us who have lived with this listen differently and patiently.
Posts.Title: Depressed sister

Posts.Content:
It all depends on what kinds of tumors you are talking about
. They were certainly checked by histology department. What did the doctors say? Were they carcinomas or other invasive cancers? Mass could mean anything.
Did your doctor approve of returning to hormone replacement? After I had breast cancer I stopped cold! But my cancer was hormone receptive and invasive. I had to take anti-hormone meds.
Age makes a difference, after the type of tumor. There is an article on this site about
 the study that shows that older women do not benefit from radiation in certain cases. I didn't need chemo, and wish I had refused rads. Radiation left me with a cooked lymphatic system on one side. I didn't tolerate the anti-hormone meds, so am "going bare" at this time and being checked - blood tests - twice a year.
Posts.Title: What are my chances if I refuse radiation and medication?

Posts.Content:
The Blues in Pennsylvania are following a lot of other companies in having their approvals first OK'd by their own people, then turning it over to a hired company for a "real" approval or refusal. The hired company gets paid by the amount they "save" the insurance company, so guess what happens to a lot of requests? By the time the real approval or refusal comes in, maybe 2 weeks later, the tests have been run and the patient may be in for an unpleasant surprise.
You can't make much of an impact complaining to your insurance. I've tried. Your doctor can appeal the decision for you though.
One thing you can try if insurance doesn't cover something is to talk to the billing department and ask if they will accept as payment what the insurance would have covered if you pay it right away. They like it lots better than taking $20 a month or so. This often comes out to 60% savings. Borrow the money somewhere and pay the bill off if you can get this kind of deal. 
 
We need to complain to our legislators to stop this insurance company practice. It's interfering with our doctors' practice of medicine and our health.
Posts.Title: Diagnostic Mammos not covered by Aetna

Posts.Content:
The doc doing the study is Josie Van Londen. I don't know if she's at MaGee or Presby. I went as a patient to give input at a meeting last May at the Kaufman Building.
My doc is with AGH. Actually, he retired and I have yet to meet his replacement, but he's supposed to be very good.
Posts.Title: post breast therapy pain

Posts.Content: Welcome dots. Have you called for an appointment with your doctor? Sorry, that's all I have to offer.
Posts.Title: Breast pain

Posts.Content:
Lymph nodes can indeed swell at any time. I just had a bunch swell up in my abdomen on my mesentary. They were painful, so they had to be drained. They can be under the arm, in the neck, anywhere lymph nodes are, and that's plenty of places.
A little needle biopsy can be done without much pain. I've had those too, back when I was young and had cysts all the time. I wouldn't agree to a big punch biopsy though, unless the docs thought there was something suspicious for cancer. I wonder why they put off doing a little needle stick right then, instead of causing you all this anxiety.
Posts.Title: swollen lymph node??

Posts.Content:
Hi Anne, welcome to the forum.
My oncologist had me get a scan when mine jumped last fall. There's more than one type. I just had the bone scan, which isn't bad at all. He's doing blood work every 3 months. My Dx was just old lady IDC with a low oncotype, rads only, but I didn't tolerate any of the hormone-reducing meds, so I have to just hope nothing shows up again.
I sure hope they caught yours before it really went anywhere. Can you talk to your oncologist about
 your anxiety? If not, maybe your family doc would help you. There's an anxiety forum here too.
Best wishes!
Posts.Title: Does anyone know much about 27-29 ?

Posts.Content:
I didn't tolerate any of the anti-hormone meds either, tried all 3 aromatase inhibitors and tamoxifen. I felt like I was 110 because of the arthritis-like pain. Docs all the time say they have never heard of it, but it's not true. It's well known. Univeristy of Pittsburgh has a study going on now. It's worse in older women.
I'm "going bare" now, getting blood tests at least twice a year, mammo annually.
I didn't need chemo, radiation left me with cooked lymphatics on one side. I needed physical therapy to break them up. It did help!
Posts.Title: post breast therapy pain

Posts.Content:
Welcome to the forum, Edna.
Yes, things seem to happen fast at first. It's terrifying. I've been in your place - all my aunts had breast cancer that spread to colon cancer. But they survived! I had a cancer found early thanks to mammo. My biopsy was a lumpectomy. If it's small there's no need to have surgery twice.
I hope you will let us know how things turned out.
Posts.Title: 14mm cluster of microcalcifications breast biopsy in 4 days

Posts.Content:
I have axillary web syndrome (aka axillary cording) even after 2 1/2 years. I just finally found a therapist who deals with it. My last oncologist said to me, "What's that?" So I'm switching again.
For me it started after radiation. My lymphatic system on the bad side was cooked - bottom of ribs to elbow.
 There are lots of exercises on the web. I've been doing them, and they do help. They just weren't enough. I'm hoping the vigorous squashing and manual stretching by the therapist will break them up.
It works for some people.
Posts.Title: MAJOR STIFFNESS/SWELLING UNDER ARMS AFTER MASTECTOMY/RECONSTRUCTION

Posts.Content:
Slash,
I'm glad you are seeing a doctor again. I hope it's a different one because you can have a second opinion. Don't get panicked. Let us know how you are getting along.
Posts.Title: Breast no pain

Posts.Content: There's always breast MRI too! I went with this before surgery. No pain, no cutting, not invasive. Insurance should cover it.
Posts.Title: Mammo vs ultrasound

Posts.Content:
My score was 7. Really low. You should talk with your oncologist about
 your risk. Onco score's for chemo, not for Aromatase inhibitors anyway. 
Don't be afraid of TRYING the meds!!! Most women do fine with them or have mild side effects. I probably didn't do well because I didn't have much estrogen to reduce in the first place. I'm a senior, had estrogen tested years ago, found very low then, was put on estradiol, which probably caused the cancer.
I'm saying that if your score is low, and you don't tolerate ANY of the meds - Arimidex was the first I tried and lasted 3 months - it's a choice to not take them at all. I chose to risk a recurrence and be able to get out of bed. 
Femara was by far more tolerable for me - you might ask the doc about
 that one. See if you can research tolerances.
Aromasin, after only 3 pills, gave me trigger fingers. It was so bad I needed surgery in 3 fingers after trying everything for several months.
Tamoxifen was absolutely no better. I can't see why they say there is any difference. I could tell it was hitting me hard after the first pill. I really tried, but it just wasn't worth living crippled up with super-arthritis symptoms.
I'm scared, but rationalizing I've had a life.
Posts.Title: Alcie

Posts.Content:
Welcome Ahna -
We' re not allowed to diagnose here, and you don't really want to rely on us patients over your doctors anyway. But we do sympathize and can tell you our stories and offer suggestions and encouragement. The self diagnosis places on the internet isn't worth much either. I've looked at some of those and they all turned out to be completely off base for my symptoms.
I would ask for another consultation to get things explained or maybe a referral to another doctor for the cough or the anxiety. Lots of things can irritate your throat. Have you seen a gastroenterologist to see if it is possibly gastric reflux/ GERD?
Your family doctor can handle all the general questions. Talking to a good cancer specialist, an oncologist, might be a good idea, especially since you have a family history.
Best wishes!
Posts.Title: Breast stuff - please help if you can

Posts.Content: I had pain same place and it turned out to be an abscess on my appendix.
Posts.Title: are there any forums on overian cancer?

Posts.Content:
Did you really need the chemo? Did you have a type that requires it?
I had a small tumor, oncotype 7, didn't need chemo, shouldn't have even had radiation from studies I have read since then. I wish I hadn't as rads made my life miserable. I didn't tolerate any of the aromatase inhibitors or tamoxifen, so I get nothing, except once a year blood test.
What are they telling you to have instead?
Posts.Title: sent home from 1st chemo tretment

Posts.Content: I saw the trailer on TV but had to do a search on CNN to find the story.  It basically says that for some older patients there was no benefit to having radiation "therapy" (my quote marks) after surgery.  I do note that this is not for everyone!
Posts.Title: CNN: No radiation after surgery OK for some patients.

Posts.Content: Has anyone else had one of these?  It's on the same side as my tumor was.  It may or may not be growing.  It's not very hard, but roundish and firm.
Posts.Title: Palpable lump doesn't show on mammogram, ultrasound, or MRI.

Posts.Content:
I had exactly the same reaction to Tamox as I did with all 3 aromatase inhibitors. They made me feel like I had had arthritis for 100 years. Aromasin was so bad it gave me 3 trigger fingers - after only 3 doses- that eventually needed surgery. Femara was a little better. I lasted nearly 6 months on it before I decided I didn't want to live like that.
I'm getting no treatment now. After a year off the meds I feel much better, although not as good as before them. I think some of the effects are permanent.
Posts.Title: Tomaxifen as continuing treatment

Posts.Content:
My biopsy for a very small cancer was the removal of the tumor. My little lump was irregular, looked like cancer on mammogram. There was no point in taking a biopsy, since it was small. 
The only hard part was it was clear back on my chest wall, so I had to go through getting 2 wires stuck into it up in radiology, then go to the OR for the surgery. I only had MAC for anesthesia - no tube down the throat. Much nicer.
Mine was malignant. I'm glad I didn't wait with a bunch of fooling around. It popped up in only a year. If it hadn't been caught then I wouldn't have been able to have it checked for oncotype. I got away with no chemo!
Posts.Title: Scheduling a breast biopsy and dont know which to choose. scared and confused.

Posts.Content: If it was me, I'd get it out. I did and mine was malignant, but not bad enough for chemo.
Posts.Title: Excisional Breast Biopsy

Posts.Content:
I commiserate with you. I'm in the same boat - AI intolerant along with most other meds.
I didn't have the DCIS, but I did have the IDC 1 cm, onco 7. I didn't tolerate ANY of the aromatase inhibitors. Femara was the best, but still made me feel like a 99 year old with unbearable arthritis. 3 pills of Aromasin gave me trigger fingers, needed surgery last summer. I haven't completely gotten over the arthritis-like effect of the AIs, and it's been over a year since I stopped the last one. My oncologist said I could just quit the inhibitors. Then I had to leave him because he moved too far away. 
I haven't seen anyone for a year and a half. Having trouble finding anyone not connected with the local hospital which has bought up all the oncology practices and charges a "clinic fee" on top of my insurance - for an office visit. My ins co told them they can't do it and it's in the contract they signed, but they do it anyway. They threaten to send me to collections and ruin my credit if I don't pay. I can't be the only one who has this problem, but nobody's doing anything about
 them.
I only get 1 check a year, from my gynecologist. I'm concerned but not hysterical. I'm not going back to the AIs.
If you check the Femara website, it says it's effective at 1/5 the dose given. There is no choice of doses though. One size-fits-all no matter your size or condition.

AgeInfo.Phrase: made me feel like a 99 year old with unbearable arthritis

Posts.Title: Aromatase Inhibitors and other news

Posts.Content:
I got several trigger fingers, both hands, from aromatase inhibitors. They popped up rather suddenly. Pain was intolerable. I think it made any arthritis symptoms that were lurking to become awful. My spine, and hips hurt terribly too. When I switched to Aromasin, worse than any of them, I had to quit even trying to take them. The trigger fingers did not get better on the right hand and I needed surgery about
 a year later.
I'm not taking anything to lower hormones now. I think I have a very low level to start with, measured before cancer as too low even for my senior age. I believe levels should be tested before putting women on pills and then not just giving all women the same dose. It makes no sense that a 4 foot 9, 95 pound woman gets the same dose as a 6 foot 2, 350 pound woman, or that a perimenopausal woman gets the same dose as an 90-year-old. 
My docs all refused to even consider allowing me to take a lower dose.

AgeInfo.Phrase: the same dose as an 90 year old <Z> <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: Arimidex

Posts.Content:
Xen - Thanks for the compounding pharmacy idea! I suppose though, that there has to be an Rx from a physician to get it done. Will a doctor prescribe something that is not an approved dose?
Right now I don't even have a medical oncologist. I stopped going to the really good one I had because he sold out his practice to the big name hospital here and got moved to a dumpy little hospital another hour away from where I was going. Also the big hospital's system of billing is to make the patient pay a "facility fee" for sitting in their chairs, just because the practice/office is within the hospital now. I had no services, no blood drawn, no treatment. My insurance went to bat for me, but I still had to pay it because I was threatened with collection and ruining my credit. I'm supposed to have all the bills sent to the insurance now, because under the contracts the clinics can't charge me this fee, but I am not sure it's going to work. Since ALL the oncology practices are now in one of the two big name hospitals or their outlying clinics, the billing is the same.
So I'm dithering about
 finding a new oncologist. It's a big pain to have all the records copied and sent to a new one - before I even know if I want stick with him or her.
I'm still suffering from pain and arthritis-like effects, even after 3 trigger finger surgeries, all brought on by these estrogen suppressors. It takes me a couple of hours to get my right hand usable in the morning - stretching in hot water, pain pills ...
Posts.Title: Aromasin - I'm stopping my last resort.

Posts.Content:
Thanks Bev -
Instead of dweling on the "right" decision I will go with the right decision at this time. I feel so much better off the meds! Since I am over 65, have had a solid tumor and a heart attack, my chance of living another 7 years is only 21%, so it might as well be without the horrible crippling AI pain.
Your point of being willing to not regret the decision is well taken. It's the best decision I can make with the information I have available. If it turns out to be wrong, well, that's in the unforseeable future.
It's time to get on with life.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> Since I am over 65  have had a solid tumor

Posts.Title: Aromasin - I'm stopping my last resort.

Posts.Content:
No surgeon, no oncologist now. They both moved when the local Univ. hospital closed down some of the hospitals. My surgery was January 2009, so it's not that long ago. I do have a gyne, so get mammos once a year. I have some little soft lumps and enlarged lymph nodes, but they don't show up, only palpable.
There is a practice I might try only 45 min away. they're owned by the U, but they have an office, so unless they call it a clinic they might not charge a clinic fee for just an office visit. I know I can't go to any of the good ones who practice out of hospitals.
I just had a good bone density, can't figure out how it went from osteoporosis to normal. So I couldn't get prescribed Evista.
Posts.Title: Aromatase Inhibitors and other news

Posts.Content: I had underarm and some same-side of body hair loss from radiation "therapy." I didn't have chemo.
Posts.Title: hair loss after therapy

Posts.Content:
I had my whole lump for a biopsy, about
 that size incision. Mine was down on the chest wall, so it hurt a little, but it's not horrible. 2 wires was the worst part - no anesthetic. Ask for a pain killer. They'll give you some Vicodin or whatever you tolerate. You might not even need it.
I always refuse Versed and Fentanyl for anesthesia. Ask before the surgery! You have the right to refuse things. Versed doesn't do anything for pain, just makes you forget. (They'll probably lie and say just something to make you relax) Fentanyl always makes me vomit for 8 hours after a procedure. I only allowed MAC for anesthesia, so no tube down the throat, breathing on my own. They don't NEED general anesthesia with tube and gas because it's a short deal. Propofol is nice because you wake up with your brain working.
Posts.Title: How much pain should I expect after an excisional biopsy?

Posts.Content:
EssPee -
I read in the Femara website that 1/5th the dose is effective. So why are we forced into a toxic dose if we don't tolerate it? I've read on other forums about
 women taking it every other day, cutting the pills in half and taking them every other day, all sorts of ways to try to reduce the side effects without going off altogether. I would have done that, but my oncologist didn't allow me that option.
I had the 3 trigger fingers operated in June and am starting to get recovered from that. I suspect the longer-than-normal recovery time may have been a late effect of the aromatase inhibitors. I need a knee operation and am thinking that might take extra long to recover too.
I stopped seeing my medical oncologist and am searching for another one.
Posts.Title: Aromasin - I'm stopping my last resort.

Posts.Content: Some of us have had to stop ALL the aromatase inhibitors and tamoxifen too. The side effects were worse than the benefits. If you have a chance of recurrence you might want to keep on with it no matter what, but with my low oncotype and severe pain, trigger fingers requiring surgery, life was the equivalent of death. I quit.
Posts.Title: Femara - anyone on it? Been on it?

Posts.Content: I couldn't tolerate Arimidex - allover pain to horrible.  I suffered through Femara for 10 months until life just wasn't worth living, getting up crying with pain every morning despite tramadol, Vicodin, Neurontin and sulindac.  I tried a 3 week "vacation" without any diminution of the pain.  Doc said try Aromasin since I have all my parts and a family history of stroke and have had a heart attack, so Tamoxifen not a great choice.
Posts.Title: Aromasin - I'm stopping my last resort.

Posts.Content:
MK
Yes, I have other healthissues: fibromyalgia, osteoarthritis in spine only with radiculopathy, 5 month ago operation for stomach shoved into chest from car wreck, which caused severe pain in wrist (continuing) from radial artery line. No mastectomy or chemo, just rads which caused axillary cording (cooked the lymphatic system on left side). I only had old lady IDC, so no reason for mastectomy. Lumpectomy = biopsy. One node - negative, oncotype only 7.
Actually the radiation caused some bad effects that are continuing: I had extreme pain and nausea requiring meds, and my blood counts dropped. This was because it was left side and the rads were hitting the ribs and the stomach. I nearly stopped, probably should have, 2/3 of the way through it. The last day I couldn't even drive myself to treatment, had to ask my DIL. The pain mostly went away after about
 3 months, but I still have low white count a year later. I'm told it is likely permanent. 
It truly is the aromatase inhibitors causing the increase in pain. It just got worse a little at a time over months while I was on Femara. I keep a detailed journal and that's clearly when pain started getting unmanageable. The stomach operation was healed after 4 months, off Vicodin after a couple of weeks. I have had fibro for years and pain was manageable until starting the estrogen-removing meds. I don't think a fibro-flare would last this long, although it certainly is a co-morbid condition. I didn't have much estrogen to start with, being post-menopausal for 20 years. But nobody measures what we're starting with and there's no dose difference for that or size or weight. I didn't have severe problems with my hands until starting Aromasin.
Now, after a week off Aromasin, I feel no better. My hands still feel like advanced arthritis, but I don't have any there. I take tramadol and neurontin when I get up (crying all the way to the kitchen) and wait for an hour for them to start working. They help with the muscle pain, but not the tendons and joints. I've tried adding Clinoril and Tylenol, but that's not giving additinal relief either. 
My fear is that if I go back on the Aromasin I will just continue to get worse. I suspect, from not having any luck with remission of symptoms after stopping, that the pain syndrome is permanent and I will be totally incapacitated if I keep on taking it.
Posts.Title: Aromasin - I'm stopping my last resort.

Posts.Content: Thanks Donna -
Posts.Title: Aromasin - I'm stopping my last resort.

Posts.Content:
Hi grammy Donna. You must be in my age group. I'm called gwamma, and I think age may be part of my AI intolerance.
Had D checked, came back 18. I started 2000 units D twice a day and it immediately helped with my fibromyalgia pain. But not the bone pains. I've been off all AIs for 6 weeks now and am feeling MUCH better. My hair is even beginning to grow a bit.
I suspect from my own experience and reading posts that it is possible that AIs mostly aggravate already existing arthritis. My pains are definitely located where I have arthritis, although mine is really very minimal. The pain resolves whan I have been off the meds for 5-6 weeks. Most posts I have read with similar complaints are from women over 40 - old enough to have a touch of arthritis which is not causing symptoms.
My tumor markers came back "normal," so my med onc said the AIs will only give me minimal benefit, and it's "up to me" to decide if I want to try again.
I'm looking for opinions from others. Given that my oncotype was only 7, no chemo, did the rads, minimal benefit (but he wouldn't give me a number, although I suspect it's less than 5%), what would you do? It is possible that I would tolerate Femara if I went back on it, because I found that part of my problem was a low D level.

AgeInfo.Phrase: complaints are from women over 40   old enough to have a

Posts.Title: Aromasin - I'm stopping my last resort.

Posts.Content:
Xen -
Thanks for the info. I'll follow up and read the Rx info again. I must have missed the part about
 the approved dose. This might help a lot of us older women who hardly have measurable estrogen in the first place. I do have a compounding pharmacy nearby.
I eat a little tomato, but none of the other nightshades. I'll have to research that idea some more also. I do have a bit of osteoporosis, which the doctors basically ignore.
The main thing I have in my favor is an oncotype of only 7. If it was higher I would probably accept being a cripple. Well, no , maybe not. But I'd probably be splitting pills or something. 
I did find out from my medicare PPO that I should have all bills for "facility fee" sent to them so they can refuse to pay and tell the hospital they can't bill me either. It's in the contract that anyone who accepts the insurance has to abide by the terms they signed!
Posts.Title: Aromasin - I'm stopping my last resort.

Posts.Content:
Jane
I started on Arimidex, but it aggravated my arthritis so much I had to stop it. It's a known side effect. I am now taking Femara with no problems whatsoever. Even my night hot flashes are reduced.
JUJU
I also have dry skin. My allergist has me using mild body oil after showering. I just pat my skin not too dry and apply the oil, or add a little water while applying it.
Posts.Title: Arimidex For Hormone Therapy, Anyone On It?

Posts.Content:
jpann -
I'm surprised they let you do the oncotype. I thought the tumor had to be less than 2 cm. But congrats on the 12! That's great!!! I hope they are now testing larger tumors and saving lots more women from chemo.
I had a 1.2 cm and a score of 7, which is extremely low. I'm totally grateful for that because with my comorbidities I probably would not have survived chemo. For me, radiation was almost too much. The last day I couldn't even drive myself for treatment.
Now if I could just tolerate Femara! I'm taking a "vacation" from it because of the pain it causes me.
Posts.Title: OncoDx testing

Posts.Content:
Hi WC -
17 sounds a bit young for breast cancer (not a doctor!), but if you have a concern about
 any condition you should consult a doctor. There are lots of other things that could cause a little lump. I wouldn't get too scared before getting a diagnosis!
Posts.Title: I have a small lump on my breast, and it doesn't hurt..

Posts.Content: If the area is truly small would they consider a lumpectomy? That's what I had, but then they were pretty sure it was cancer. The big center that did the MRI wanted to do a biopsy, but my surgeon in a smaller center said the lumpectomy was the biopsy.
Posts.Title: ultrasound

Posts.Content:
Becky -
Maybe a pain clinic doc could come up with a nerve block for you. Some spinal nerves run around to the front. I had an injection last week that surprised me by running to my bely button.
Posts.Title: Nerve pain in breasts

Posts.Content:
Jocelyn -
How did they decide you didn't need rads? I was told it was standard and even with an extremely low risk of recurrence and negative (one) lymph node, I was not given a choice or counceled in any way about
 whether I needed it or not. 
I didn't need chemo, wouldn't have survived it with my sensitivities, allergies.
Posts.Title: CNN: No radiation after surgery OK for some patients.

Posts.Content: When I turned 40 I had a mammogram that was so painful it left me bruised.  Then, since I had a small cyst, I was talked into an aspiration which I couldn't afford at the time and spent a whole year paying for.  So I didn't go back for 20 years.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> When I turned 40 I had a mammogram that

Posts.Title: Mammogram trauma and findings?

Posts.Content:
Onc won't have anything to do with it, neither will gyne. I did get a new surgeon (old one moved too far away), but he says just to get another mammogram in 6 months and see him then. I was hoping he would biopsy. Since this is the cancer breast and has had 65 grays rads and a year of AIs, I'm hoping it is benign. He thinks it is but didn't have a name for it.
I do appreciate the info about
 pseudolump and fibroadenoma. I will do more searches. I read tons of medical stuff when I get something. It really helps me relax even if surgery is called for. If I know what to expect I'm not scared. 
Thanks again!

AgeInfo.Phrase: cancer breast and has had 65 grays rads and a year

Posts.Title: Palpable lump doesn't show on mammogram, ultrasound, or MRI.

Posts.Content:
Thanks so much for the info. Since I can't convince anybody right now to do a biopsy, I'm forced to just monitor the lump myself until the next mammogram. I can't understand how something you can feel doesn't show up on mammogram, ultrasound or MRI!
I'm suspecting, after some cursory reading, that it just might be the suggested (above) pseudolump, maybe from fat necrosis. A cyst should have shown up on tests. I think it was first there shortly after the (single) lymph node removal (clean) and the radiation "therapy." I had methylene blue dye, which is noted for causing fat necrosis - which a webpage says may be a cause of pseudolumps. They're also supposedly caused by radiation. (I refused tats but got 3 permanent blue spots from the dye anyway.) Areola shrank to half or less thickness, nipple is hiding in there somewhere. I also got axillary cording from the rads. So pseudolump sounds reasonable. It's definitely not hard or immovable, so chance of being benign is higher.
If there's any change you can bet I'll squawk! There's no reason for any fuss about
 how to find it for a biopsy since it's near the surface and can be felt.
If anybody else has suggestions I'll look up anything I have to. I just don't have too many ideas or education on lumps.
Posts.Title: Palpable lump doesn't show on mammogram, ultrasound, or MRI.

PatientDecided.Sample: Severe pain, horrible arthritis-like symptoms, fingers curled until I ended up with trigger finger surgery. I lost some hair that didn't come back, but that could have been radiation....First Aromasin pill was nearly as bad as the first Arimidex, which caused me to pass out. I had headache, severe nausea (scarey because I can't vomit since stomach surgery to pull my stomach out of my chest after car wreck), horrible muscle cramps in thighs, chest pain, and severe dizziness from low blood pressure to the point where I couldn't get off the couch long enough to get a phone across the room to call for help....I ended up having trigger finger surgery from the effects of the meds. After a year being off the meds I am still not interested in sex, and it hurts too much to even try....I tried all 4 meds, didn't tolerate any of them. Severe pain, horrible arthritis-like symptoms, fingers curled until I ended up with trigger finger surgery....They all gave me such pain, all the other side effects, that I had to stop taking anything. I ended up having trigger finger surgery from the effects of the meds....I had headache, severe nausea (scarey because I can't vomit since stomach surgery to pull my stomach out of my chest after car wreck), horrible muscle cramps in thighs, chest pain, and severe dizziness from low blood pressure to the point where I couldn't get off the couch long enough to get a phone across the room to call for help. Second pill, today, much better taken with a large breakfast....
